items.title: Siyob Bazaar_189
items.description:
ValKamch posted a photo:

Siyob Bazaar is located adjacent to the Bibi-Khanym Mosque, and is visited not only by local people but also by domestic and foreign tourists.

Сиабский рынок имеет очень удобное расположение, всего в нескольких минутах ходьбы от него находится большая мечеть Биби-Ханым. Территориальная площадь рынка довольно внушительная – торговые ряды раскинулись на более чем пяти гектарах земли. Вход на базар выполнен в виде возвышенной трехстворчатой арки, украшенной мозаикой в сине-голубых тонах. Торговые ряды располагаются под навесами, которые защищают рынок летом от знойного солнца, а зимой от ветров и осадков.
items.author: nobody@flickr.com ("ValKamch")
items.tags: colorful colour market multicolored red tomato trade vegetables красный красочные овощи помидор рынок товар томаты торговля цвет самарканд samarkand samarqand uzbekistan свежие

items.title: Pilaf center_218
items.description:
ValKamch posted a photo:

In Uzbekistan pilaf is prepared in each city. It is a local sight, visiting which, you will have a desire to go back there again. This place is called “Pilaf center”, where pilaf is cooked by oshpaz (master on pilaf cooking). Pilaf is cooked here in several huge cauldrons with capacity from 60 to 100 kg of rice. What is the secret of such a marvelous taste? Firstly, it is the knowledge of classic recipe that masters -oshpaz use it in their preparation. Secondly, it is the best rice imported from areas of theFerganaValley, fresh products and, of course, the master’s hand.

В Узбекистане плов готовят в каждом городе. Это местная достопримечательность, посетив которую, у вас возникнет желание вернуться туда снова. Это место называется “Центр плова”, где плов готовит ошпаз (мастер по приготовлению плова). Плов здесь готовят в нескольких огромных котлах вместимостью от 60 до 100 кг риса. В чем секрет такого изумительного вкуса? Во-первых, это знание классического рецепта, которое мастера -ошпаз используют в своем приготовлении. Во-вторых, это лучший рис, привезенный из районов Ферганской долины, свежие продукты и, конечно же, рука мастера.
items.author: nobody@flickr.com ("ValKamch")
items.tags: cooking dishes eggs meatdishes pepper rice vegetables course dish food mess блюдо еда кулинария мясные овощи перец посуда рис яйца самарканд samarkand samarqand uzbekistan

items.title: Potato Peelings
items.description:
raaen99 posted a photo:

The theme for “Looking Close on Friday” for the 3rd of June is “food peels”. Luckily, I was making some mashed potato to top a cottage pie the day the theme was announced, so I saved some of the potato peelings. I took a few possible photos of them in my hand and on chopping board, however they didn’t particularly inspire me. I felt I needed something else to help lift them, and then it came to me. Anyone who follows my photostream knows that I love and collect 1:12 size miniatures which I photograph in realistic scenes. The artifice of recreating in minute detail items in 1:12 scale always amazes me, and it’s amazing how the eye can be fooled. Therefore, to lift the image of the peelings on a chopping board, I thought I might add some miniatures that reflected what I was doing to get these peelings. So, I have added a miniature chopping board, four very realistic looking potatoes, a kitchen knife with a serrated edge and a saucepan with peeled potatoes inside it, soaking in water. I hope you like my whimsy for this week’s theme and that it brings a smile to your face.

All these miniatures are 1:12 scale, and some are artisan pieces.

The potatoes are artisan miniatures from a specialist stockist of food stuffs called Beautifully Handmade in Kettering in England. They have a dizzying array of individual food items and meals which is always growing, and all are made entirely or put together by hand, so each item is individual.

The kitchen knife with its inlaid handle and sharpened blade comes from English miniatures specialist Doreen Jeffries Small Wonders Miniature store.

The saucepan of potatoes in water is made in England by former chef turned miniature artisan, Frances Knight. Her work is incredibly detailed and realistic, and she says that she draws her inspiration from her years as a chef and her imagination.
items.author: nobody@flickr.com ("raaen99")
